thread.title: Erie's Flagship Funds grant program now open for small businesses to apply
thread.title_full: Erie's Flagship Funds grant program now open for small businesses to apply

author: Jade Leah Burns
title: Erie's Flagship Funds grant program now open for small businesses to apply
text:
WJET Erie Erie’s Flagship Funds grant program now open for small businesses to apply Jade Leah Burns Thu, January 9, 2025 at 11:09 PM UTC 2 min read
Calling all small business owners and entrepreneurs!
The City of Erie has opened its latest round of Flagship grants financial assistance.
This program can assist businesses with a wide variety of needs and will now continue to transform and make a difference for small business owners.
The City of Erie’s administration has been investing in small businesses since 2018 giving away more than $300,000.
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Mayor Schember offers update on city’s LERTA program
Officials announced that they are continuing this trend by opening their Flagship Funds micro-grant program to applicants starting Thursday, Jan. 9.
According to the director of office development, it’s designed to provide financial assistance to support market-ready products and services while also serving to enhance the city’s reputation for innovation and creativity.
“A lot of the economic development programs are geared towards larger projects, there’s not a lot out there for small business so we wanted to make sure we had something that could assist small business directly,” said Chris Groner, director for the City of Erie’s Office of Development.
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Close
Thanks for signing up!
Watch for us in your inbox.
Subscribe Now
Daily News All you have to do is be a registered business with an address in the City of Erie.
Groner said they prefer businesses with 25 employees or less.
Those who apply can get up to $5,000 with a one-to-one match requirement.
“Usually businesses match it more than one to one so that’s a good sign. That means investments coming into the city, but it’s going to the small business,” Groner added.
With the PACT Act expanded, what does that mean for Erie veterans?
One business owner who’s a two-time recipient said not only did these funds help her to open but it allowed for improvements along the way.
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement More in Business Bugatti Bolide’s First U.S. Track Outing Delivers Unparalleled Thrill at COTA Modern Car Collector US firm to bury nuclear reactors 1-mile underground to power data centers Interesting Engineering How Much Savings Middle-Class Retirees Have, According To Most of America GOBankingRates Are banks, post offices, shipping services closed on Jan. 9, the national day of mourning? USA TODAY “It helped with the equipment in the space that you see and the other increment was for marketing, trying to get the word out in the Erie community about Purrista,” said Dena Rupp, owner of Purrista Cat Cafe. “It’s not an opportunity that comes along all the time, and we struggle too sometimes, we need a little bit of help.”
Rupp brought this fresh idea to the area that’s popular in larger cities such as Pittsburgh and Cleveland.
The cat cafe is located at 30 West Eighth St. and will be celebrating three years this February. They host up to 15 adoptable cats from Because You Care animal rescue.
Erie City Council unanimously passes two-page version of Tenant Bill of Rights
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Rupp said they have had 295 cats rescued and adopted since they opened.
“We’re all trying to do the best we can. Small businesses are such a huge part of this community. It makes Erie unique and I think they are a very huge part of what’s important here in Erie,” Rupp explained.
The application deadline is Jan. 31. If you would like more information, click here.
